turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Pazhou.
turn.1: What were the modes of transport in the pre-modern period?
turn.2: Typically, cargo was ferried from the ships by its own crew and to the ships at the expense of the Chinese merchants on their "chop boats" (lighters).
turn.3: What were the trade routes in the pre-modern period?
turn.4: To avoid theft or piracy, foreign traders began assigning a few of their own seamen to these ships as guards.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: In 1686, Westerners were allowed to rent accommodations in the factory quarter to avoid the necessity of shuttling back to Pazhou each night.
turn.7: What jobs were available in the factory quarter?
turn.8: For the most part, the supercargos, their assistants, and the bookkeepers stayed at the factories, the crew—except for a few guards or those on shore leave—stayed with the ships, and the captains continued to ferry between the two.
turn.9: What types of social interactions took place in the pre-modern period?
turn.10: A comprador () dealt with the ship's provisions at Pazhou, where sampan ladies crowded around the ships to do laundry and odd jobs for the sailors.
turn.11: Did they have any laws or social policies in the pre-modern period?
turn.12: As an added layer of defense and revenue, city officials continued to enforce anchorage at Pazhou even when smaller private craft began to trade in increasing numbers following the mid-18th discovery of the Philippine route allowed them to come and go without waiting months for the monsoon winds.
